07430.description: Pony Power Therapies is looking for volunteers to assist with our \" All HANDs In\" ( Horse Assisted Nature Driven) after-school enrichment program. All HANDs In provides an interactive, farm-based, non-riding enrichment program that offers participants, ages 14 - 21, the opportunity to enjoy a unique and unparalleled after-school experience. Sample activities include Grooming horses, lead-walking horses, preparing a whole food-based afternoon snack, stall and barn management, small animal (goats & pigs) care, and planting and care of the farm's fruits and vegetables. RESPONSIBILITES Work under the direction of the Afterschool Program Coordinator/Structured Learning Instructor Assist program participants in activities Provide one on one educational or physical assistance as needed Set up and break down of program materials/supplies Attend required trainings/meetings ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS FOR ENRICHMENT PROGRAM ASSISTANT Mandatory training with Afterschool Program Coordinator/Structured Learning Instructor. Minimum age of 17 years with reliable transportation Must be able to commit to a full semester of programing (10 to 12 weeks - Tuesday and/or Thursdays afternoon from 4 to 6 PM) Must be able to lift 30 pounds Must be able to physically participate in a 90-minute session in both indoor and outdoor activities. SCHEDULE: Tuesdays: Mar 20 Mar 27 Apr 10 Apr 17 Apr 24 May 8 May 15 May 22 Jun 5 Jun 12 Thursdays: Mar 22 Mar 29 Apr 12 Apr 19 Apr 26 May 10 May 17 May 24 Jun 7 Jun 14 Interested volunteers can contact volunteers@ponypowernj.org or call 201-934-1001 for more information.
07430.title: After School Enrichment Program Assistant

07430.description: Pony Power Therapies is looking for Lead Walkers and Side Walkers for our Therpeutic Riding Lessons on Thursday mornings. We have several schools that bring up to 7 students each Monday through Thursdays. (Only those with previous horse experience will be assigned as Lead Walker). Please email for our handbook, application and a list of upcoming training classes.
07430.title: Volunteers Needed for Thursday Morning School Group Therapeutic Riding Lessons!

07430.description: ENROLLMENT FOR VOLUNTEERS FOR PONY POWER THERAPIES SPRING SEMESTER IS NOW OPEN! Pony Power Therapies is looking for volunteers to assist in therapeutic horse-back riding lessons as lead walkers for our Spring Semester! Lead walkers are responsible for handling the horse during lessons and only those with previous horse experience will be assigned as Lead Walkers. Lessons run Sunday through Thursday. Our Spring Semester begins on Sunday, March 4th and runs through to June 21st. Volunteer Handbook, application and schedule will be emailed to you and application needs to be returned to our office prior to registering for a volunteer training class. Pony Power Therapies gives special needs and at-risk children and adults a unique opportunity to ride, care for and interact with horses. Our riding and non-riding activities enhance individuals' physical, social and emotional well-being in a safe, nurturing farm environment. Please visit www.ponypowernj.org for more information on Pony Power Therapies. Interested individuals can email volunteers@ponypowernj.org or call our office at 201-934-1001.
07430.title: Horse Handler Volunteers for Pony Power Therapies!

07430.description: ENROLLMENT FOR VOLUNTEERS NOW OPEN FOR PONY POWER THERAPIES' SPRING SEMESTER! Pony Power Therapies is looking for volunteers to assist in therapeutic horse-back riding lessons as side walkers for our Spring Semester! Under the supervision of a certified riding instructor, the side walker walks next to the horse to provide support to the rider as needed. Lessons run Sunday through Thursday. Our Spring Semester begins on Sunday, March 4th and runs through to June 21st. Volunteer Handbook, application and schedule will be emailed to you and application needs to be returned to our office prior to registering for a volunteer training class. Pony Power Therapies gives special needs and at-risk children and adults a unique opportunity to ride, care for and interact with horses. Our riding and non-riding activities enhance individuals' physical, social and emotional well-being in a safe, nurturing farm environment. Please visit www.ponypowernj.org for more information on Pony Power Therapies. Interested individuals can email volunteers@ponypowernj.org or call our office at 201-934-1001.
07430.title: Side Walker Volunteers for Pony Power Therapies!

07302.description: America Needs You fights for economic mobility for ambitious, first generation college students. We do this by providing transformative mentorship and intensive career development. Our New Jersey program workshops take place in Jersey City or Newark Career Coaches work with college students during Saturday sessions to build their professional skills and help them realize their career potential. ANY curriculum covers all kinds of professional development topics from resume preparation and interview etiquette to giving and receiving feedback and managing up. At workshops, Career Coaches typically participate in group or one-on-one work with Fellows; for example, writing and reviewing a cover letter or building a pros/cons list for deciding between two internships. RSVP to an upcoming workshop on April 28th or May 19th in Jersey City: anynjcareercoach.eventbrite.com
07302.title: Volunteer to mentor ambitious, first-generation college students in Jersey City!

11554.description: ComeUnity Sports is a competitive training and exercise program for adults with intellectual and developmental disabilities - our Starz! Our Starz Track and Field Team has begun practicing and is looking for additional volunteers to assist with coaching and competitions. Practices take place on Monday nights at the East Meadow High School. Volunteers should come dressed to exercise alongside the athletes and should arrive no later than 6pm. Volunteers will be asked to assist athletes while they train for events such as, the 100, 200 and 400 meter dash, standing and running long jump, modified javelin throw, modified shot-put (softball throw) or the the 4X100 relay. No track and field experience is necessary just a desire to help and a lot of energy. A full schedule including competitions can be provided upon meeting with the volunteer coordinator. Requirements include: Online application Orientation training For more information about this or other volunteer opportunities contact Justin McDannell at 516-626-1000 ext. 1303 or jmcdannell@ahrc.org. To apply today please go to www.ahrc.volunteerhub.com.
11554.title: ComeUnity Sports Track and Field

11554.description: The American Liver Foundation Greater New York Division is looking for volunteers to help out at the 2018 Liver Life Walk in Long Island. Event duties include: Event Set-up Duties: Assist in hanging banners, setting up tables and chairs, decorating etc. Registration Duties: Welcome participants as they check-in, pick-up their t-shirts and receive detailed information about the day. Parking Attendants Duties: Direct vehicles to empty parking spaces one at a time. There will be an area for volunteers to park separate from participant parking. Also, parking attendants will assist with placing directional signs to designate where the event is being held. Course Set-up Duties: Place route markers and educational signs throughout the walk course approximately every few blocks so walkers/runners are able to stay on the course. Responsibilities also include: 1. Deliver tables, water and cups to water stations 2. Drop-off water station volunteers and course monitors 3. During the Walk, patrol the course to pick-up any tired walkers 4. Follow the final walkers to pick up the course monitors and water stop volunteers 5. Return to the course to pick up the remaining water, cups, tables and signage Course Monitors Duties: As a Course Monitor, you will be stationed at specified intersections along the course to help participants cross any busy intersections and cheer them on to the finish. You might be asked to wear a bright orange vest to distinguish yourself. Greeters Duties: This is every participant's first impression of the event! Greet participants after they have parked and direct them to the registration area. Tent Supervisors Duties: We will be having several tents with food, drinks, games, etc. so we will need people to oversee that everything is going smoothly. Please note: We are happy to provide proof of volunteer time for those who need it for schools, community service, etc. If interested, please contact Logan Moore at lmoore@liverfoundation.org.
11554.title: 2018 Liver Life Walk Long Island
11554.org: American Liver Foundation Greater New York Division

06807.description: Organized, energetic, creative and detail-oriented person interested in helping execute our much loved 24th Annual Garden Party at the Riverside Yacht Club, Riverside CT. Responsibilities include: *Assist Development Director & Marketing Coordinator in the execution and management of the silent auction, including the solicitation of auction items, managing spreadsheets, creating bid sheets and displays for the event. *Assist in the soliciting of local businesses for underwriting and sponsorship pledges. *Manage and help with mailings such as save-the-date and formal invitations. *Manage relationships with vendors, including caterer, party rental, liquor vendors and venue. *Help stage event venue for over 250 guests. Help assist with the management of promotional and event materials such as props and backdrops. *Assist with event ticket sales. *Work with public relations and social media to promote event *Answer logistical questions and help create invitation lists based on sponsorships, ticket sales and such.
06807.title: Development/Special Events Coordinator

11217.description: Responsibilities: Assist Billing Manager with any billing responsibilities. Help with annual budget, keeping up with operational billing standards, providing analysis of each department, helping to identify and resolve billing problems, and tracking status of bills. Overall Responsibilities: -Must support and maintain mission goal and statement of organization. -Assist in drafting and the finalization of bills, sending to recipients. -Reaching out to each department maintaining monthly statements and balances. -Assist in preparing a monthly billing statement for entire organization. -Ensure billing and payment information are accurate and up to date. -Assist in identifying and resolving invoice disputes and errors. -Monitor status and dates of bills. -Process and maintain invoices through spreadsheets and files. -Working with each department for yearly budget. Competencies: -Has/working towards a degree in accounting, finance or related field. -Experience with bookkeeping. -Excellent organizational and communication skills. -Competency with Google docs, Quickbooks, and Microsoft Office, particularly Excel and Quickbooks.
11217.title: Billing Department Assistant

11217.description: We are currently seeking 1-2 people to help us out with the following for our Parents support group of children being affected by cancer: 1. Assist with securing new Support Group sponsors 2. Communicate with vendors to secure deliverables, gift certificates and logos to properly thank them on social media 3. Attend support group events to establish a relationship with parents and care takers to improve retention of participants. 4. Assist with securing meeting and or event space. 5. Keep a running list of attendees to inform them of upcoming activities.
11217.title: Administration Volunteer

11217.description: READ 718 is looking for volunteer literacy tutors for our Spring cycle (April 9-June 21, 2018). Volunteers must attend an orientation and one training session. READ 718 is a non-profit literacy center that provides afterschool tutoring and literacy workshops to low-income students in grades 3-8. We are looking for dedicated, reliable, caring, positive people who are committed to working with a child twice a week for 10 weeks (April 9-June 21), excluding Public School vacation dates. Tutors will be provided with easy-to-follow lesson plans for each session, and will have access to reading specialists for questions and guidance. Children who are behind in reading after grade 3 and do not receive the targeted instruction that they need simply fall further and further behind. READ 718 aims to provide students with high quality, supplementary instruction to bridge the gap between students who are struggling and their grade level peers. If you are interested in being a volunteer tutor, please visit our site and complete application at: http://read718.org/volunteer-application/
11217.title: Volunteer Literacy Tutor

11217.description: This Program deals with businesses who are interested in joining with A Free Bird. Things such as product placement can occur with A Free Bird, getting a large portion of the proceeds for a certain time period. This requires a lot of patience and persistence from the individual who wants to be the Coordinator. Reaching out via email, phone, and speaking to companies and following up with companies that you did not receive an answer from. Thinking outside of the box, we are looking for someone who has the ability to come up with incentives for companies to collaborate with A Free Bird and how they will benefit from working with us. Following up with companies that you have reached out to and see if they are interested in the program. Coming up with ideas for companies to work with the AFB and help raise funds for our Programs Dept. Travel to companies location. Have available 10-12 hours per week to devote your time to the organization Be comfortable with Google Docs creating forms and excel spreadsheets to keep track of companies Organized and professional demeanor Great communication skills. Willing to work individually as well as in a team. Be comfortable on all social media platforms and use it to reach out to many more individuals.
11217.title: Get Excited Coordinator Volunteer

11217.description: A Fundraising Program which enables the public to provide direct sponsorship to the child. Reaching out to companies and individuals who are willing to sponsor a child that the organization has within the Programs Department. This person must feel comfortable with phone calls, speaking to people in person, and reaching out via email. You will report back to the VP of Fundraising, creating graphs and charts using the Google Docs. Must be comfortable with Social media and be able to post about the organization and what sponsor a child has to offer the community. Being in contact with the Programs Department on the children that are available and what company will be sponsoring which child. Have availability of 10-12 hours per week. Understanding of Google Docs, and Excel Spreadsheets Organized and professional Great Communication Skills Be fluent on all social media platforms. Willing to work individually as well as in a team environment. Report back to the VP of Fundraising with progress as well as the Founder of the organization. Have some availability on the weekend. Be comfortable on social media platforms
11217.title: Sponsor a Child Coordinator Volunteer

11217.description: This is a program where we are given and pass along free instruments to the children so that they can use it to practice their musical talent. We also donate equipment to hospitals. This person must be able to feel comfortable reaching out to companies via email, phone, as well as in person. Must be willing to find musical instruments that companies either would like to donate or give away to the organization and then give to the children. Person must be willing to travel and give instruments to children and take photos for our social media pages. Working closely with the Programs Department and with the coordination of events where the children will receive the instruments as well as coordinating times that the children will be available to meet with you and the programs department to drop off the instruments to the children. Be ready to work with moving companies. Be organized as you will be keeping track of the instruments we have available. Must feel comfortable sending emails, speaking over the phone, and speaking in person to people. Great communication skills and technical skills when it comes to devices. Must be willing to travel to the storage unit and childs home as well as the hospital Be available 10-12 hours per week. Must be available to come into the office and work from home Must have own laptop/computer to work from and have a smartphone device Familiar with Google Docs Willing to work individually as well as in a team. Be comfortable with social media as you will be posting and reaching out to companies via social media outposts.
11217.title: Give Arts Coordinator Volunteer

11217.description: A Free Bird is a 501(C)(3)non-profit organization based in New York City. Our focus is to provide children, ages 4-18 who are patients or survivors of juvenile cancer, the opportunity to explore their artistic passions and give them the strength to fight their disease. We believe that artistic expression is critical for healing! A Free Bird supports children affected by cancer in their exploration of art, music, acting, poetry, writing, singing and any other artistic passion they may have. After a very incredible and successful year and in order to help as many kids as possible, we are seeking a Public Relations Coordinator/Manager volunteer who can commit 15-20 hours per week for a minimum of 3 months(150 hours). Responsibilities: Working with a small team, conceptualize and implement traditional and social media strategies and campaigns aimed at generating coverage of AFB's programs, key advocacy issues and marketing and celebrity-driven campaigns. In Collaboration with our Social Media Director and Marketing Coordinator Produce blogs and other content for external publication. Edit commentaries produced by other AFB staff. Coach and supervise PR Intern Assistants. In Collaboration with our Social Media Director and Marketing Coordinator Expand and nurture AFB's mainstream and social media network. In Collaboration with our Social Media Director and Marketing Coordinator Build and manage our Twitter-sphere. In Collaboration with our Social Media Director and Marketing Coordinator Help manage the AFB's media database, build lists and track media coverage. Qualifications: Excellent writing and editing skills with ability to produce polished and compelling copy on tight deadlines Creativity in tapping and cultivating mainstream media and social networking communities Keen insight into the news business and understanding of what makes journalists tick Proven ability to identify and market good story ideas Prefer candidate with local or hyperlocal media relationships A positive, energetic and proactive multi-tasker who can work independently or very collaboratively, as part of a team Ability to work effectively, efficiently, diplomatically and calmly in a high-pressure environment on issues that are often complex and politically sensitive Strong listener, with a high degree of professionalism and flexibility, including the ability to prioritize and effectively manage assignments in a timely fashion
11217.title: PR Social Media Coordinator

07023.description: The Service-Learning Instructor assists in facilitating The Need2Read Program Inc.'s community service program for 7th grade students from various districts including Scotch Plains-Fanwood, Plainfield, Westfield, and Cranford. The instructor uses pre-approved lesson plans and activities to help students become informed about the links between poverty and illiteracy while also teaching students the importance of planning in life with a segway into the importance of proper lesson planning for a literacy program. Students are challenged to break into teams, select from a group of random items and create their own lesson plans for a specific age group. The following week, each team visits a local shelter partnered with our organization and they host a 1-hour literacy program with the children in the shelter program. The program finishes off with a lesson in identifying literacy challenges in our own communities among our peers and is followed up with a subsequent literacy day for the community. The literacy day is planned by the students and all games are created or reinvented by the students. They invite their collective communities, family, and friends out to the event where students are awarded and recognized for their work. Lesson plans, activities, and supplies are provided to the instructor. The group will meet on Thursdays April-May. One Wednesday evening (6:30pm-7:30pm) is also required for the visit with homeless youth. The Literacy day event will be held on Saturday, May 19th from approximately 12pm-3pm. For more information about our organization please visit: www.TheNeed2Read.org and our Facebook page at: www.Facebook.com/TheNeed2Read
07023.title: Seeking Short-term Instructor for 7th Grade Service-Learning Program

07960.description: Tour de Summer Camps NJ is a community-wide cycling event put on by The Jewish Federation of Greater MetroWest New Jersey. Proceeds from the ride will fund One Happy Camper grants and need based scholarships to give more local children the opportunity to attend a Jewish summer camp. This year’s event will take place on Sunday, April 29 and features an 18, a 36, and a 62 mile route for our cyclists as well as a family-friendly route on the College of St. Elizabeth's campus. There will also be a Family Fun Day happening at our Start and Finish for riders of all ages and anyone interested in learning more about the Jewish summer camps in the area. Volunteers for this shift will dceer at the finish line, pass out water, snacks and medals, and assist with wrap-up.

07960.description: Tour de Summer Camps NJ is a community-wide cycling event put on by The Jewish Federation of Greater MetroWest New Jersey. Proceeds from the ride will fund One Happy Camper grants and need based scholarships to give more local children the opportunity to attend a Jewish summer camp. This year’s event will take place on Sunday, April 29 and features an 18, a 36, and a 62 mile route for our cyclists as well as a family-friendly route on the College of St. Elizabeth's campus. There will also be a Family Fun Day happening at our Start and Finish for riders of all ages and anyone interested in learning more about the Jewish summer camps in the area. This volunteer shift helps direct riders to and from parking locations and the start line.
07960.title: Parking/Greeter and Directional Volunteer - Tour de Summer Camps New Jersey
07960.org: JEWISH FEDERATION OF GREATER METROWEST NJ

07960.description: Tour de Summer Camps NJ is a community-wide cycling event put on by The Jewish Federation of Greater MetroWest New Jersey. Proceeds from the ride will fund One Happy Camper grants and need based scholarships to give more local children the opportunity to attend a Jewish summer camp. This year’s event will take place on Sunday, April 29 and features an 18, a 36, and a 62 mile route for our cyclists as well as a family-friendly route on the College of St. Elizabeth's campus. There will also be a Family Fun Day happening at our Start and Finish for riders of all ages and anyone interested in learning more about the Jewish summer camps in the area. This volunteer shift will help with final preparations and will cheer on the riders from the start line.
07960.title: Morning Cheer Squad and Set Up - Tour de Summer Camps New Jersey
07960.org: JEWISH FEDERATION OF GREATER METROWEST NJ

07960.description: We are requesting the following: 10 volunteers for setup/breakdown and execution of event Food donations from vendors: subs, sandwiches and/or pizza cotton candy machine and supplies kid's craft corner clown/character photographers
07960.title: Donations for goods/services needed for Great Strides-MORRISTOWN
07960.org: Cystic Fibrosis Foundation Greater New Jersey

07960.description: We are beginning to recruit interested volunteers for our upcoming New Jersey Confidential Sexual Violence Victim Advocate (CSVA) training, which is slated to begin in February 2018 (10 Weeks, Tuesdays from 6PM-10PM). During the 40 hour training volunteers are educated about topics regarding sexual assault statistics, prevention, and response. Crisis intervention and advocacy support skills are taught and guest speakers, including law enforcement, military experts, and mental health professionals present information. When the volunteer completes the training and receives the CSVA status, they are required to manage the crisis hotline for three 12 hour shifts per month. (The hotline is forwarded to the volunteer's telephone for their shifts.) In addition to hotline, the advocate's second responsibility per shift is to accompany survivors of sexual assault to the hospital as needed. Although this is a challenging volunteer position, the experience is very rewarding (and looks great on a resume too)! Join our team and support survivors!
07960.title: Sexual Assault Response Team Advocate Training

07621.description: We are running free after schools for children underprivileged in order to give chances for them to get self esteem and confidence in learning. Most of our kids are immigrants who are struggling to settle down in new circumstances. You can teach our children so that they can share what they learned from you with others in future. Any kind of talent that makes our children happy is greatly appreciated. We have one free after school in Palisades Park and the other in Bergenfield, New Jersey. We will resume 3rd one in Northern Virginia. Classes are from 4:00 to 6:10 PM from Monday to Thursday.
07621.title: Homework Tutoring

07009.description: The New Jersey Heart Ball, attended by more than 450 individuals from New Jersey's corporate, medical, pharmaceutical, and social communities, is the annual black-tie gala benefitting the American Heart Association's lifesaving mission of building healthier lives, free of cardiovascular disease and stroke. For more than 20 years, the New Jersey Heart Ball has promoted the American Heart Association's mission on a local level and thanks to our donor support, we have seen inspiring advances in the fight against heart and stroke related illnesses. Your support is crucial to the success of the event! Please keep in mind that once you commit to being a volunteer, we're counting on you to attend, participate, and have some fun! We encourage all volunteers to be flexible with their responsibilities throughout the evening, as we may need to make last minute changes as the evening progresses. Some of the volunteer jobs: - Registration assistants - Greeters - Check out assistants - Set-up/breakdown - Live auction assistants - Seating assistants - Open Your Heart spotters - Silent auction monitors - Silent auction greeters - Mobile bidding concierge - Directional assistants - Silent auction runners
07009.title: NJ Affair of the Heart Ball

10306.description: Great Strides is the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation’s signature event and its largest and most efficient nationwide fundraising campaign. This year, Great Strides will raise over $43 million in an effort to add tomorrows to the lives of all those living with cystic fibrosis. Join the Greater New York Chapter on Sunday, June 10th (Midland Beach, Staten Island) and help us prepare for Great Strides 2018. Check-in, opening ceremonies and breakfast will begin in the morning. The walk will conclude with entertainment, our Kid’s Korner, family festival, lunch, closing ceremonies and much more. Listed below are descriptions of various volunteer roles. Your help will ensure that Great Strides 2018 is a huge success! Set-up & Signage Greeters Registration Route T-Shirt Distribution Food Distribution Clean-up Contact Shara Swift, Senior Development Manager, at 212-986-8783 or by e-mail at sswift@cff.org for more information or to sign up!
10306.title: Volunteer at the 2018 Great Strides Walk in Staten Island!
10306.org: Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, Greater NY Chapter, Manhattan Branch

10302.description: About The Volunteer Role: MRNY is seeking a volunteer with teaching experience to teach a citizenship class to ESL students looking to pass their naturalization exams to become US citizens. MRNY offers a collaborative environment for volunteers who take part of this opportunity. The volunteer will: Look closely at the materials and lesson templates provided by our staff to adapt the lesson plans/materials to fit a 2 hr class. Send the MRNY staff materials for printing or bring printed material (we have a printer in the office available for your use). Teach the civics class on Mondays to multi-level English learners seeking to take a naturalization interview. Communicate during the evening with the volunteers recruited to do mock exams to ensure that students are given adequate practice Maintain effective communication with the team regarding anything that seems unclear, questions s/he may have, the status of the class and the students, and other things related to the class. We also ask that volunteers respond in a timely manner to emails from staff about the class. Training and support that MRNY can provide: Orientation about MRNY materials for citizenship class General Orientation (about MRNY, the volunteer role, the students, community, collaborative approaches, etc...) A couple of class observation in our Queens location (the volunteer observes the citizenship classes taught by MRNY staff in our Queens location) Phone meetings (scheduled with the volunteer) A room for teaching Student enrollment and pre-testing Printer, laptop, projector and speakers are available for use Our Volunteer Community: It is important to us that participants have a strong desire to support and work with the immigrant community. Great teamwork, effective communication skills, a positive attitude, and an interest in adult education as it relates to student speakers of other languages, or the desire to learn about these is required from all our volunteers. ​
10302.title: Strengthen Immigrant Communities- TEACH A CITIZENSHIP CLASS

10301.description: We are Community Agency for Senior Citizens, Inc. We have been in Staten Island for over 40 years. We only serve Older Adults. The program is called the Friendly Visiting Program. The program began in January/2017. We look to \"Match\" you with an Older Adult. The program asks that you spend one hour in the Client's home. While visiting the Client, you can have a cup of coffee/tea, play a table top game, cards, read a book together, watch a movie. The visit is what you both decide upon. This is a building block relationship. So far, many of our \"Match's\" have become good friends and look forward to these weekly visits.
10301.title: Do You Want to Brighten Someone's Day? Volunteer's Are the Sunshine that Homebound Adult's Need
10301.org: COMMUNITY AGENCY FOR SENIOR CITIZENS INC

07701.description: The Salvation Army in Red Bank needs volunteers to assist with our After School Program providing homework instruction to students aged between 6-12 years old. Volunteers may also be required to lead or help with educational activities. Complete CHRI - Criminal History Records Information Finger Printing Requirement (The Salvation Army will provide the information required to complete the fingerprinting request) NO COST TO VOLUNTEER www.bioapplicant.com/nj All Volunteers must provide a copy of a Health Physical from a Doctor stating that they are in good health. This can be provided by their primary doctor, an urgent care, or even the campus medical facility. All Volunteers must get a TB-Tuberculosis Test done before beginning work with the children. This can be provided by their primary doctor, an urgent care, or even the campus medical facility. Complete State required childcare Background Check CARI -Child Abuse Record Information (The Salvation Army will provide the information required to complete the background check) NO COST TO VOLUNTEER. : 3:00pm3:00pm3:00pm3:00pm To: 5:30pm5:30pm5:00pm5:00pm
07701.title: After school homework/ reading help- Red Bank
07701.org: The Salvation Army - New Jersey Division

07701.description: Our Afterschool Feeding Program continues a long tradition of providing for children’s most basic needs ultimately striving to address deeper or long-term issues. We provide an afterschool meal on Monday and Wednesday, to 21 children many of whom count on The Salvation Army for a meal to end their day. We provide these meals in two shifts, 3:15 and around 3:30. Volunteers should be able to lift at least 50lbs and be able to work with a diverse group of people. Volunteers should enjoy working with children and previous experience volunteering with children would be a plus. The volunteer should also work well with others and be willing to work as part of a team. The volunteer should also be dependable, responsible and committed.
07701.title: Afterschool Meal Prep
07701.org: The Salvation Army - New Jersey Division

10029.description: Bring a friend (senior) to lunch. We need 4 to 5 volunteers to help Keep track of the seniors that brought a friend and give them a raffle ticket Help decorate Help serve food, drink, and prices Help clean after the event is over. Volunteers will need to be here by 10:30am to set up. The event will be from 11:30 am to 3 pm. Volunteers will report to Sacha Tapia When: Monday, April 16th Where: 2205 First Avenue ( 114th Street First Avenue) Time: 10:30am - 3pm Please reply to Jeanette Iturbides at jiturbides@unionsettlement.org or 212.828.6103
10029.title: Bring a friend (senior) to lunch

10029.description: Volunteer with Behind the Book (www.behind the book.org), a non-profit literacy organization that inspires New York City public school students to explore stories and empower their voices. Through our innovative programs, which are part of the class curricula, accomplished authors visit high-needs pre-K-12 classrooms to guide students in creating their own writing and art projects based on the theme of the author's book. You need no experience or training to volunteer. As a classroom coach, you'll support and encourage students as they work on their projects. This workshop needs your help in East Harlem, NYC. To volunteer, reply with the program code to volunteer@behindthebook.org. We'll supply the address, directions, and other information when you're confirmed: Program 3752RWG-H Date: Tuesday, April 17th Time: 9:30 - 11:00 AM Volunteer Role: Writing Coach About the workshop: Second-graders read Bottle Cap Boys by Rita Williams-Garcia, about two African-American brothers who make tap shoes with bottle caps to dance in the streets. With the help of coaches, students will polish their essays based on their research into the history of New Orleans and bottle-cap dancing. For dates of other workshops around New York City, please visit http://www.behindthebook.org/current-volunteer-opportunities/ To join our team and receive announcements of new classroom programs and other opportunities as they're scheduled, please complete our brief questionnaire at http://www.behindthebook.org/join-us/volunteer/
10029.title: Writing coach for East Harlem NYC public school literacy program (375rwg)

10029.description: Union Settlement Senior Services is looking for Volunteers willing to provide their services to Seniors during National Volunteer Week. Seniors will be recognized for their countless volunteer hours to our Senior Centers daily. Volunteers will provide their services to help decorate the site, serve food and refreshments, socialize with the seniors, and help with clean up. Help us thank and recognize volunteer’s efforts on Wednesday, April 18th from 10:30 AM to 3 PM. When: Wednesday, April 18th from 10:30am to 3pm Where: Union Settlement in East Harlem (237 East 104th Street) Interested individuals or groups should email Jeanette Iturbides -Volunteer Coordinator at Jiturbides@unionsettlement.org
10029.title: Food & Beverage Volunteers Needed for Senior Volunteer Celebration

10029.description: This is a great opportunity for someone that cares about healthy eating and the environment. Help us set up the Central Park East II Spring Fair. This year's theme is \"Recycle, Up Cycle, Reuse.\" We will have electronics recycling, Bike New York, Blender Bikes, African dance, food, story telling, archery, science demonstrations and much more. We need help setting up tables and preparing for the event. Please let us know if you have a skill or talent related to our theme.
10029.title: School Spring Fair

10029.description: Thank you for your interest in volunteering with NYC Parks. Street Games is an annual event that re-introduces classic, low-tech games played in the city in the 60s and 70s to a new generation of kids. The event is open to all ages and abilities. We are looking for volunteers to help support the overall event: including but not limited to providing instruction and or oversight of event programming ( i.e. skully, double dutch) managing lines and crowds and fulfilling general event operations. To register as a volunteer, please complete this form https://goo.gl/forms/Nl4rFWmueOntduy73 If you have any questions, please contact Venus Melo at Venus.Melo@parks.nyc.gov with Street Games Volunteer in the subject line. Please note that at this time we are only accepting volunteers over the age of 18.
10029.title: Volunteer at Street Games - April 28, 2018
10029.org: NYC Department of Parks and Recreation

10029.description: Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade. Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life. With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency. No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm. Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.
10029.title: Become a reading partner- make a lifelong impact on a child (PS 38 Roberto Clemente, NYC)

10026.description: Each Wednesday, we prep & serve a simple vegetarian meal offering in Central Harlem for anyone who needs a meal. One can help cook and/or serve and/or clean up. Time commitment is flexible: 2 & 1/2 hours to prep/cook, 1 hour to set up/serve, 1 hour clean up. One can help out with any part of the meal. Any level of skill is accepted.
10026.title: Volunteer To Cook & Serve Every Wednesday

10026.description: Come enliven the intellect and spirit of the youngest of curious learners who are ages 3, 4, or 5! In our program, you will work with a Teacher to support the teacher in her classroom instruction. You will have the opportunity to practice your craft of becoming an early childhood instructor. Lessons that will be facilitated will concentrate in the areas of Science, Engineering, Robotics, and Art. Literacy and Math circle times will also be incorporated. Though your coursework may not concentrate in the area, as many early childhood programs do not, that's ok. Your study or experience in early childhood education is welcomed. If you are student of Education, you are welcome to develop lesson plans that center around a specific topic in your coursework, as well as video that lesson and obtain feedback from the Teacher of record. If you are an early childhood teacher, and you are in transition or are retired, you are welcome to contribute your mastery in our space. Thank you in advance!
10026.title: Calling Early Childhood Student Teachers! We're Looking For STEM PreK Instructors

10027.description: We need a web developer to build a new website for our Brain-based Holistic Training center in Harlem! It's an exciting new project we have and we want to put all our energy and passion into it. Unfortunately we don't have the funds to pay for a web designer so we would really appreciate it if you have the expertise and can donate your time to this exciting project. The website will be off of our \"heaquarters\" website and would need to flow well with it: www.ibreafoundation.org. Please feel free to reach out with any questions. Thank you! Isabel
10027.title: Web designer for Holistic Training Center website

10027.description: The Boys and Girls Club of Harlem is committed to providing access and opportunities for youth to reach their full potential. General Support Volunteers help achieve that goal. The Boys and Girls Club serves members from 5-18 and increasing the adult to member count allows a more meaningful experience for members. Support volunteers allow us to run programs more effectively because there are more individuals to assist in facilitation. Key Responsibilities: Club Support volunteers will assist club staff as well as members to ensure a fun and safe environment for all. This role is to ensure our members are getting the most out of their club experience. Provide programmatic and operational support to the organization. This could be academic support, walking students to different programs and assisting staff with program facilitation.
10027.title: General Support Volunteer

10027.description: Market Access Program Intern Start Small Think Big (Start Small) is a not-for-profit organization located in Harlem. Our mission is to help under resourced individuals build and sustain thriving businesses in order to increase their personal financial security and stimulate economic activity in underserved communities in New York City. We believe that entrepreneurship results in increased innovation and sustained economic growth for everyone, in particular, those most traditionally marginalized. The Market Access Program Intern will work with the Marketing Program Manager to assist our entrepreneurs with marketing and sales business needs. This includes developing resource guides, learning more about sales opportunities in NYC and online, and supporting our communications team with a social media strategy. Job Responsibilities shall include, but are not limited to: Assist in managing Start Small Think Big social media platforms, including creating and posting content, identifying influencers in the space, and responding to comments and questions received from entrepreneurs. Research and develop informative resource guides focused on assisting entrepreneurs in identifying and addressing business challenges and community resources necessary to increase business success. Support the Marketing Program Manager in delivering services, via workshops, consultations, and project-based relationships, this includes managing logistics of events, coordinating entrepreneur attendance, and all necessary follow-up calls. Assist in developing the evaluation rubrics used by volunteer marketing experts to help entrepreneurs identify weaknesses in their current marketing practices. Preferred Skills/Qualifications: Current undergraduate student with strong interest in writing, social media, and communications, nonprofit program management, or other related disciplines. High level of computer proficiency including familiarity with Google Applications, social media (Facebook, Instagram and Twitter) and MS Office. Knowledge of programs: Buffer and Canva a plus. Demonstrated commitment to inclusive community/economic development, social and economic justice work, and/or anti-poverty work. Excellent verbal and written communication skills, time management, and interpersonal skills; Highly organized, creative and self-motivated; a strong problem-solver and analytical/critical thinker; and Experience working in low-income and/or immigrant communities. TO APPLY: Submit resume to: Eliza Edge, Market Access Program Manager at eliza@startsmallthinkbig.org (include subject line: \"[your name] Market Access Program Intern.\" This position is unpaid, but may be used for course credit where appropriate. Minimum 10 hours/week at our office. Hours are flexible. Start Small Think Big is an equal opportunity employer with a standing policy of nondiscrimination. This means that all qualified persons are accorded an equal opportunity for employment or promotion without regard to actual or perceived race, religion, color, national origin, ancestry, disability, medical condition, marital status, sex, age, sexual orientation, gender identity or expression, family responsibility, personal appearance, genetic information, matriculation, or political affiliation.
10027.title: Market Access Program Intern

10027.description: The High Expectations Department at HEAF is looking for a Youth Leadership Council YLC volunteer instructor to assist students with event planning, completing projects, and participating in organizational efforts to increase community service. The instructor(s) will bring students together to strengthen their leadership skills, relationship-building, and presentation skills. Students will partner up with community organizations to put on either fundraising events and/or service projects. YLC is a student led group, and students will also establish a HEAF centered project. Goals of the Youth Leadership Council: To empower students to participate in their own communities through stewardship. To educate students on keys issues in the community. To give students an opportunity to interact with each other and the community in a positive, constructive way. To provide opportunities to build leadership skills, self-esteem, social skills, and interpersonal relationships. Responsibilities of YLC Instructor: Design and facilitate 90 minute lessons on leadership and service learning Assist students with organizing and implementing community service events Guide students’ intellectual curiosity as they explore issues and challenges facing their community Support students growth into leaders and global citizens Qualifications /Requirements Current college students, college graduates, or graduate students Volunteer should have an interest in community service and youth leadership Volunteer must have experience with group facilitation and event planning Has a personal interest in education and youth development Patient and personable with youth Must be highly motivated
10027.title: Youth Leadership Council Instructor

10027.description: Harlem Educational Activities Fund, Inc. HEAF is seeking dedicated and passionate individuals to serve as academic coaches to provide tutoring and support to our College Quest (High School) students, grades 9-11. Our students need your help in the following subject areas Middle School: English Language Arts (ELA), Math (ratios, percentages, decimals, single variable equations, solving for X, plotting points on a graph) and Social Studies Time Commitment: 2:30 - 4pm, Saturdays High School: English, History (Global, U.S), Math (Trigonometry, Geometry, Algebra), Physics, Biology, Chemistry, Earth Science, Spanish, French Time Commitment: 2:30-4pm, Saturdays About HEAF: The Harlem Educational Activities Fund, Inc. (HEAF) is a comprehensive not-for-profit supplemental education and youth development organization that supports and assists dedicated students to develop the intellectual curiosity, academic ability, social values and personal resiliency they need to ensure success in school, career and life. HEAF identifies scholars in middle school and supports them until they are successfully admitted to four-year colleges through a variety of after-school, Saturday and summer programs. Academic Coach Position Summary: HEAF seeks talented, passionate individuals to work with our high school students to ensure their academic success. HEAF’s College Quest program operates on weekdays from 4:30-6:30pm. Academic Coaches are asked to make at least a one hour/week commitmentfor a minimum of one semester. Academic Coaches provide assistance in core subjects such as Math, English, Science, and Social Studies. Coaches are matched with students based on the coach’s skills in specific subject areas and the student’s needs. Academic Coach Responsibilities: Assess and assist students in at least one of the core subjects Assist students with homework, projects, and test preparation Evaluate and record student progress Attend and participate in scheduled tutor orientation & training meetings Communicate academic progress to program staff Complete and submit required documentation Create a rich learning environment that aids in instructing students with various learning styles General Requirements: Desire to work with and motivate high school students to achieve academic success Some College or B.A. (Masters students in Education encouraged to apply) Advanced skills in Mathematics, English Language Arts, Science, Social Studies, and/or SAT Test Prep Experience tutoring high school students Strong work ethic and professional values Strong interpersonal skills Willingness to promote HEAF educational and youth development philosophy. Ability to work collaboratively with the HEAF staff Ability and willingness to commit to academic year Bilingual (Spanish/English) candidates are highly encouraged to apply. *This position is unpaid
10027.title: Academic Tutor (Brooklyn)

10027.description: Sports Journalism Writer for Asphalt Green’s Community Sports Leagues Newsletter About Asphalt Green Asphalt Green is a not-for-profit organization dedicated to assisting individuals of all ages and backgrounds achieve health through a lifetime of sports and fitness. Our three main community programs reach over 33,000 New Yorkers and include: Waterproofing, which teaches elementary school children how to swim; Recess Enhancement Program, which sends a \"play coach\" to schools to get kids active during recess; and Community Sports League (CSL), which provides Harlem middle school students the chance to play interscholastic organized sports. Job Description As an integral member to the Community Sports League staff, you will be responsible for producing fun, highly detailed and engaging game write ups. You will write out the play by play, interview players, take action shots and choose your game MVP. Your submission will be included in the weekly newsletter and given out to all league participants. Location: Asphalt Green--555 East 90th Street Hours: Soccer, Saturdays 7:00pm - 9:00pm, Basketball Saturdays 10:00am-12:00pm Duration: January 2018 - June 2018 Duties: -Take notes on games every Saturday -Write a recap of each game in the style of a sports reporter. Who were the stars? Was it a close game? Was there a comeback? -Interview players, parents, coaches to add to your piece -Type up your notes and send to our newsletter coordinator by Tuesday morning -Provide general assistance to AG’s CSL staff in maintaining order and a safe, positive environment Qualifications -Excellent writing skills -Must be able to meet deadlines and respond to emails quickly -Must be creative, outgoing and able to speak with kids in a relatable way in order to get fun and full stories -Background in Sports, Communications, or other related discipline is a plus
10027.title: Sports Journalism Writer for Asphalt Green Community Sports Leagues Newsletter

(HEAF) is a comprehensive not-for-profit supplemental education and youth development organization that supports and assists dedicated students to develop the intellectual curiosity, academic ability, social values and personal resiliency they need to ensure success in school, career and life. HEAF’s College Quest program operates on weekdays from 4:30-6:30pm. Academic Coaches are asked to make at least a one hour/week commitment for a minimum of one semester. Academic Coaches provide assistance in core subjects such as Math, English, Science, and Social Studies. Coaches are matched with students based on the coach’s skills in specific subject areas and the student’s needs. Academic Coach Responsibilities: Assess and assist students in at least one of the core subjects Assist students with homework, projects, and test preparation Evaluate and record student progress Attend and participate in scheduled tutor orientation & training meetings Communicate academic progress to program staff Complete and submit required documentation Create a rich learning environment that aids in instructing students with various learning styles General Requirements: Desire to work with and motivate high school students to achieve academic success Some College or B.A. (Masters students in Education encouraged to apply) Advanced skills in Mathematics, English Language Arts, Science, Social Studies, and/or SAT Test Prep Experience tutoring high school students Strong work ethic and professional values Strong interpersonal skills Willingness to promote HEAF educational and youth development philosophy. Ability to work collaboratively with the HEAF staff Ability and willingness to commit to academic year Bilingual (Spanish/English) candidates are highly encouraged to apply. *This position is unpaid
10027.title: High School Academic Coach (Tutor)

11225.description: We are a 501 (C) 3 non profit organization dedicated to inspiring and nourishing children with cancer through the arts. A Free Bird will be hosting it's 3rd Annual Gala on November 16th and we are in need of volunteer photographers and videographers. You will receive credit for photos/videos used as well as a special mention in our brochure. We are seeking people who have done photographer/videography before at big events and know how to create incredible stills. We ask a few photographers/videographers show up when we do for setup at 11:00am. The event ends at 9:00pm so the latest we would need you is until 9:30/10:00pm. For clean up and sometimes the events goes over a bit, other photos might need to be taken as individuals are leaving.
11225.title: Photographer/Videographer Volunteer

10025.description: The event volunteer will help administer one of our six fun, interactive, hands-on games that teach kids about sustainability.
10025.title: Event Volunteer Round 2

10025.description: Whether you're great, good or fair at Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM), you can help make an impact on inner-city youth. Here's how: The Parris Foundation S.T.E.M.ulating Minds Weekend Enrichment Program has returned for the Spring 2018 session. The program began after a successful summer pilot in 2012, and our subsequent programs have grown to continue to serve middle school students and high school students . With the growing impact on the community, we need your support to continue to bring STEM to our middle school and high school youth throughout New York City. As we expand to more locations to serve more youth, there is a growing need for volunteers! How we do it: The Parris Foundation curriculum combines innovative and interactive software and teaching techniques with hand-ons interdisciplinary experiments and activities to keep our students engaged with their passion for science and math! About The Parris Foundation: The Parris Foundation is dedicated to promoting educational opportunities and fostering awareness in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) through scholarships and community outreach programs. The Parris Foundation's S.T.E.M.ulating Minds: Weekend Enrichment Programs provide extended learning opportunities to supplement and enhance in-school learning.
10025.title: Spring 2018 - S.T.E.M.ulating Minds Weekend Enrichment Program

10025.description: Top Honors is a non-profit educational organization that provides free math tutoring to NYC 5th, 6th, 7th, and 8th-graders. Tutoring takes place on Saturdays and Wednesday evenings at a school on the Upper West Side. New volunteer orientation and training sessions take place on a rolling basis. To receive an invitation, please submit an application here. Frequently asked questions about the TH volunteer experience can be found on our website. All tutoring sessions take place on the Upper West Side in Manhattan on the following days and times: Session 1: Saturdays from 10 a.m. to 12 p.m. Session 2: Saturdays from 1 p.m. to 3 p.m. Session 3: Wednesdays from 6:30 p.m. to 8 p.m. Volunteers may be professionals, advanced high school, college, or graduate students (community service credit is available). Applicants should be available on Saturdays for two hours starting at 10 a.m. or 1:00 p.m. or on Wednesdays from 6:30 - 8 pm, like math, and enjoy working with students in the middle school age group (10-14 years). No prior experience is necessary. A note on volunteer commitment: Tutors attend 2-3 Saturdays from October and May, which includes holidays and school breaks. Attending 22 out of 27 scheduled sessions will meet this requirement. To apply, submit an online application at www.tophonors.org/volunteer. Upon receipt, Top Honors will contact the candidate directly.
10025.title: Do you love MATH? Volunteer MATH Tutors needed!

10023.description: Hola! Somos una organizaci?n sin fines de lucro que ayuda a la comunidad inmigrante latina y no latina de Nueva York en el aprendizaje del idioma ingl?s, en la preparaci?n para el examen de ciudadan?a estadounidense y en el desarrollo de otras actividades de empoderamiento para la comunidad inmigrante. Tambi?n ofrecemos clases de espa?ol para no hispanohablantes, con lo cual contribuimos adem?s a la difusi?n de la cultura y valores hispanos en los Estados Unidos. Estamos a la b?squeda de profesores de Espa?ol (voluntarios) para nuestras clases de primavera 2018 (mayo 3 - junio 22 2018). Las clases son una vez por semana (jueves) de 6:00 pm a 9:00 pm. Esta es una posici?n de voluntariado (sin pago). Si te gusta ayudar a la gente y a la comunidad por favor comun?cate con nosotros respondiendo este aviso. Habr? una sesi?n de entrenamiento previo al inicio de clases fecha tentativa. Muchas gracias!
10023.title: Volunteer Spanish Teachers

10023.description: Centro NYC seeks dedicated volunteers with a passion for intercultural exchange and learning who can be available weekday evenings to ensure the smooth running of our ESL and Spanish programming at our new home near Lincoln Center. Core responsibilities: -Greeting students and managing class check-in, as well as new student registrations -Facilitating nightly \"intercambio\" break sessions between classes, by preparing/breaking down snack preparations, managing snack sales, and encouraging students to practice language skills -Participating in major marketing initiatives for the organization -Admin office tasks such as assisting teaching staff, checking voicemails and returning calls Commitment: Volunteers will be expected to meet either Tuesdays OR Thursday evenings from 6:00-9:00pm beginning Tuesday, May 1 st and ending on Thursday, June 21 st. We also hope volunteers can be present during our end of term celebration on Friday, June 22 nd. If time constraints exist, there may be flexibility around start/end times for shifts. Eligibility: Foreign language experience a plus. How to apply: Email us at info@centronyc.org or apply through our volunteer form online. About us: Centro NYC (El Centro de Educación de Trabajadores) has provided a place of community and assistance for recent immigrants in New York City since 1975. Learn more about us at centronyc.org and facebook.com/CentroNYC2018/ Volunteers find a real sense of community at Centro, often staying for many years, and bringing their friends, family, and coworkers to join too. Volunteers themselves are welcome to take any class offered free of charge.
10023.title: Operations/Admin Volunteer - Tuesday or Thursday Evenings

10023.description: Centro NYC, a non-profit organization serving the immigrant community in New York City, seeks volunteer ESL teachers for its 2018 spring term, beginning May 1 and continuing through June 22. However, we hope that you will continue to volunteer with us in the fall. Classroom English teaching experience is preferred. However we do recruit new teachers with strong English communication skills and a good feel for grammar, even if you don't know all the rules! New teachers are partnered with and mentored by experienced teachers. Time commitment: One Tuesday or Thursday evening per week teaching plus the time required for lesson preparation (usually every other week.) Classes meet Tuesdays and Thursdays from 6:30-9:00 p.m. near Lincoln Center in Manhattan, and teachers are asked to arrive 6-6:15 to set up. In addition, there will be one staff meeting in April, and possibly one mid-semester. We have openings for teachers of beginning, intermediate, and advanced students. Please respond by email to Susan at susan@CentroNYC.org. Include your resume and tell us the evening(s) that you're available for teaching. Learn more about us at centronyc.org and facebook.com/CentroNYC2018/
10023.title: Adult English / ESL Teachers ? VOLUNTEERS NEEDED!

10023.description: Event Preparations A team of ten Volunteers are needed to help set-up and event, May 19th 2018. 11:00 am to 4:00 pm Positions Sign-in-Desk- 2 Volunteers Room Set-up all Volunteers Bar Table ( wine and water) 2 volunteers Food table- three Volunteers, (finger food) Room Monitors- 3 Volunteers If you are interested please contact my by April 10th, 2018 The position will be removed when we reach the amount needed. I can be reached at descort@projectfind.org Please visit our web-site www.projectfind.org
10023.title: Volunteer  Cecbration

10023.description: Help us assemble and \"delineate\" the AIDS Walk New York route before the Walk starts and break down the route once walkers have completed it. Delineator Volunteers must be comfortable with physical activity and lifting. Be prepared to get a little dirty! AIDS Walk Shift: Sunday, May 20 from 7 a.m. - 4 p.m. Meet at Central Park West and 72nd Street.
10023.title: Delineators - AIDS Walk NY 2018

10023.description: Our business internship program provides a unique opportunity for volunteers to economically empower small business owners in east Africa. After learning about each business owner’s situation and challenges, volunteers present ideas, opportunities, and solutions. After the internship program, participants will be able to put international consulting, leadership, and other valuable experiences on their resumes. Volunteers will also have the opportunity to experience a world-class safari at the end of the trip. Because the program is strengthened by diverse experience and expertise, the program is not limited to business minds only. All are welcome to apply. www.marafikiafrica.org
10023.title: Volunteer as a Business Intern in Africa!

10023.description: Our pre-health program is specially catered to students preparing for medical school and other health professions. During the course of the trip, volunteers explore health, hygiene, and nutrition in the developing world. We have the ability to cater the experience in Africa to medical school, dental school, nursing school, and other pre-health career needs. Volunteers gain valuable first-hand experience in clinics, orphanages, and communities. We will be happy to write a letter of recommendation on your behalf at the end of your service. Volunteers will also have the opportunity to experience a world-class safari at the end of the trip. www.marafikiafrica.org
10023.title: Volunteer as a Medical Intern in Africa!

10023.description: Volunteers participate in the development of impoverished communities in East Africa by partnering with village leadership and the community. In most cases, leadership in remote areas seek help in accomplishing their goals for education, health, and business but often lack sufficient resources and expertise to achieve those goals. Marafiki Africa volunteers help them to achieve their goals and experience the rich culture of East African tribes. A few examples of past projects include a water pipeline, school restoration, medical clinic restoration, and hygiene kit distribution. Volunteers will also have the opportunity to experience a world-class safari at the end of the trip. marafikiafrica.org
10023.title: Volunteer in Africa!

10020.description: Assemble start up baking kit Assemble start up baking kits and literacy bags for the families in our Bronx programs. Come have some fun and make a difference!
10020.title: Assembling Baking Basics Kit and Literacy Bags
10020.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

10020.description: Formed in the aftermath of Tuesday’s September 11 th , Tuesday’s Children is dedicated to providing a lifetime of healing to individuals and communities around the world whose lives have been forever changed by terrorism, war and traumatic loss. Take Our Children to Work Day is one of the organization’s largest annual events. This event will take place on Thursday, April 26 th in New York City, Washington DC, Boston, and Jacksonville, Florida. Take Our Children to Work Day offers a unique opportunity for children impacted by terrorism and war to participate in a valuable workplace experience that allows them to envision their future through a practical, hands-on work day in an industry of interest to them. Past participating companies include: Etsy, the National Hockey League, Tradeweb, Lokai, LinkedIn, Youtube, the Mets and many more! We are looking for chaperones who can spend the day with our kids in New York City. Chaperones accompany a group of children to and from their assigned placements, and remain at the placement for the duration of the program. Chaperones will need to meet at a location in Midtown Manhattan on the morning of Thursday, April 26 th to meet their groups. Breakfast will be provided. From this location you will take your small group of participants to their company for the day.
10020.title: Take Our Children To Work Day Chaperone with Tuesday's Children

10021.description: Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, widely recognized as one of New York's premier human services providers, is a 124-year old settlement house that provides an extensive array of effective and integrated services which significantly improve the lives of 15,000 people in need each year on the East Side of Manhattan. Our English as a Second Language program provides high quality, interactive instruction to a diverse student body. We seek to increase students' language skills, confidence in speaking and comprehension of English. Volunteers are needed to teach one class per week on Fridays, 9:30am-12:00pm from April 13 - June 15. Training and supervision are provided but volunteers will need to prepare weekly lesson plans for their class and write brief summaries of student progress.
10021.title: English as a Second Language Instructor

10021.description: We need a lot of help on Saturday, May 19 preparing for the big event! Help set up the Teams Area, assemble the Sign-In Area, and assist with the placement of posters. This volunteer position is great for those who prefer to walk on Sunday, May 20. Saturday, May 19 from 10 a.m. - 2 p.m. Meet in Central Park at Rumsey Playfield.
10021.title: Saturday Setup - AIDS Walk New York 2018

10021.description: Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, widely recognized as one of New York's premiere human services providers, is a 124-year-old settlement house that provides an extensive array of effective and integrated sevices on Manhattan's East Side. Our CARE program is an arts-based day program for older adults with dementia. The program provides a caring and engaging environment that allows participants to be involved in group and indvidulaized activities, while providing a respite for family caregivers. As a volunteer Program Assistant you will assist staff in leading therapeutic activities such as visual and performing arts projects, live music performances and health and welllness programs for our participants.
10021.title: Program Assistant - CARE Program for Older Adults with Dementia

10021.description: We are seeking a Japanese speaker to meet with a senior that speaks Japanese as part of Lenox Hill Neighborhood House's Friendly Visiting Program. Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, in partnership with the NYC Department for the Aging, connects volunteers with homebound older New Yorkers to have in home visits on a regular basis. For volunteers, friendly visiting offers the opportunity to cultivate a lasting friendship, to learn from a senior’s life experiences, and to benefit from the personal satisfaction derived from community service. Friendly visiting leads to the creation of meaningful relationships between older adults and volunteers, promoting intergenerational understanding. For the senior, friendly visiting provides a sense of connection to the outside world, something to look forward to, and a sense of contributing to society through sharing their wisdom, knowledge, talents and stories with you. Tasks: Have weekly social, in-home visits with an older adult you are matched with Provide monthly reports/updates to the Friendly Visiting program coordinator Requirements: Commit to being a Friendly Visitor for a minimum of six months Be comfortable establishing a relationship with an older adult Honest, mature, motivated, patient Ability to maintain confidentiality Willing and able to contact the program coordinator should problems arise Participate in an in-person interview Undergo and pass a background check and provide references Email monthly report of hours to coordinator
10021.title: Japanese Speaking Friendly Visitor Needed

10021.description: Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, widely recognized as one of New York's premiere human services providers, is a 123-year old settlement house that provides an extensive array of effective and integrated services which significantly improve the lives of 15,000 people in need each year on the East Side of Manhattan. We are seeking volunteers who can translate short informational documents from English to Spanish in order for us to better serve the many Spanish speakers who seek help from our Legal Department for issues related to affordable housing, healthcare, workers' rights and eligibility for social service benefits.
10021.title: English/Spanish Translation

11743.description: Help young parents learn to give positive behavioral feedback to their pre-school children. Volunteers interact with the childen in planned activities while the group leader counsels with parents. Thursdays from 1:00 - 3:00 in Huntington.
11743.title: Mommy and Me
11743.org: Family Service League of Suffolk County

11743.description: Who doesn't love the warmth and unconditional love from a beautiful four legged furry pet? If you love dogs, and I mean, really love dogs then you can be part of a rewarding experience. Our exclusive Pet Therapy program is currently looking for chaperones. We have committed pet therapy handlers who bring their trained and certified dogs to the hospital to visit our patients. As a chaperone you will be . . . escorting the handler and dog to the patient floors on various units. engaging and interact with our patients & families and wonderful caregivers. providing hand sanitizer to all who pet the dog. greeting patients and introducing the pet handler and pet therapy dog. able to commit to one day a week for a maximum of 2 hours, usually not more than an hour. The presence of a dog in a hospital setting allows the patients to feel more at home, as they do play a small part of the healing process. The immediate gratification you will see on the patients' and staffs' faces when they are interacting with the dog is truly amazing. There are known benefits for pet therapy visits . . . improves mood and overall well-being decreases stress and anxiety lowers blood pressure lets patients reminisce about their own animals If you are interested in volunteering in our program, please contact me for an interview. Alice Messina Patient Liaison Pet Therapy Coordinator 631-351-2399 amessina2@northwell.edu
11743.title: Pet Therapy Chaperone

07043.description: WE NEED VOLUNTEERS TO HELP USHER GUESTS TO THEIR SEATS, MANAGE THE MEET AND GREET FOR VIP TICKET HOLDERS AND DIRECT TRAFFIC FROM THE PARKING LOT TO THE TRANSPORTATION BUS OR WALKING PATH TO THE AUDITORIUM. WE WILL ALSO NEED VOLUNTEERS TO HELP SET-UP AND BREAKDOWN AT THE BEGINNING AND END OF THE EVENT. ADDITIONALLY, WE ARE LOOKING FOR VOLUNTEERS THAT WANT TO HELP US FUNDRAISER FOR THE EVENT.
07043.title: Health Fair and Movie

11428.description: Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade. Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life. With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency. No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm. Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.
11428.title: Become a reading partner- make a lifelong impact on a child (PS 33 Edward M. Funk, NYC)

11422.description: We are looking for volunteers who can assist with the curriculum. We will have six workshops on the third Saturday of each month , 12-2pm. We are also planning a cultural enrich field trip plus community service days. Volunteers will help facilitate the workshops and the events. We are looking for a retired teacher that could possible serve on the board
11422.title: Help4AYES

Distribute snacks and beverages to our dedicated walkers. Help direct walkers to services such as restrooms and first aid. All ages are welcome! This volunteer position is great for families and groups. AIDS Walk Shift: Sunday, May 20 from 8 a.m. - 3 p.m. Report directly to your assigned Checkpoint. Specific instructions and location assignments will be given at the orientation. Mandatory Orientation: Saturday, May 19 from 12 p.m. - 1 p.m. Meet in Central Park at the Naumberg Bandshell, northeast of Sheep Meadow.

Direct walkers on the venue, guard restricted areas, and help answer their questions. Energetic and outgoing personalities are a must! Info Army Volunteers must be at least 18 years old. Mandatory Orientation: Saturday, May 19 from 12 p.m. - 1 p.m. Meet in Central Park at the Naumberg Bandshell, northeast of Sheep Meadow. AIDS Walk Shift: Sunday, May 20 from 7 a.m. - 3:30 p.m. Meet in Central Park at Volunteer Sign-In, located at the Naumberg Bandshell, northeast of Sheep Meadow.

10019.description: Keep AIDS Walk New York green! We need volunteers to lead the way in preserving the beauty of Central Park. Help tell walkers what they can compost or recycle and how to do it. Sunday, May 20 from 6:30 a.m. - 12 p.m. Meet in Central Park at Volunteer Sign-In, location at the Naumberg Bandshell, northeast of Sheep Meadow.

10019.description: Help us as we process donations and tally the funds turned in by our participants on the day of AIDS Walk New York. Totaling Tent Volunteers must be at least 18 years old and have some experience with a 10-key calculator. Sunday, May 20 from 10 a.m. - 4 p.m. Meet at the Star Walker’s Tent in Central Park.

10019.title: Security - AIDS Walk New York 2018

10019.description: Route Marshals direct the flow of participant traffic and help keep walkers safe at key intersections along the Walk route. This allows them to get a great front-row seat and cheer on walkers as they go by! They must be outgoing, energetic, and good communicators in order to guide the walkers safely. Route Marshals Volunteers must be at least 16 years old or accompanied by an adult. Sunday, May 20 from 6:45 a.m. - 2:30 p.m. Meet at Central Park West and 72nd Street.
10019.title: Route Marshals - AIDS Walk New York 2018

10019.description: Be the first to welcome back the walkers! Help us celebrate at the finish line by handing out Seals of Completion and cheering as the walkers return from the route. Then stick around to help us make sure the venue is spotless and beautiful. Sunday, May 20 from 10:30 a.m. - 3 p.m. Meet at Checkpoint 4, located in Central Park at the Naumberg Bandshell, northeast of Sheep Meadow.
10019.title: Finish Line Hooplah! - AIDS Walk New York 2018

Distribute snacks and beverages to our dedicated walkers. Help direct walkers to services such as restrooms and first aid. All ages are welcome!
